title: 112_hr3120
content: The "Student Visa Reform Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes an accreditation requirement for colleges and universities. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change the requirements for student visas at accredited colleges, universities, and language training programs in the United States. The term "Attorney General" is replaced with "Secretary of Homeland Security." The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change student visa requirements at accredited colleges, universities, and language training programs in the United States. The term "Attorney General" is replaced with "Secretary of Homeland Security." The term "accredited college, university, or language training program" is defined as institutions accredited by a recognized accrediting agency. SEC. 3. OTHER REQUIREMENTS FOR ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS. Section 214(m) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to require accreditation of academic institutions for certain nonimmigrant students. The institution must have 25 or more alien students pursuing a course of study and meet other specified criteria. The Secretary may waive the accreditation requirement in certain cases. The Secretary of Homeland Security can waive the accreditation requirement for academic institutions with nonimmigrant students if they are in compliance with the law and making efforts to meet the requirement. Individuals convicted of certain offenses cannot hold key positions in accredited institutions authorized for nonimmigrant student attendance. Institutions must maintain records for the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System as required by the law. Offenses that disqualify individuals from key positions in accredited institutions include violations related to peonage, slavery, trafficking, transportation for illegal sexual activity, unlawful bringing of aliens into the US, and fraud. The curr_chunk relates to fraud and misuse of visas, permits, and other documents in an academic institution's participation in the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. Amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding fraud and misuse of visas in academic institutions participating in the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. The amendments made by sections 2 and 3 of the Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and apply to nonimmigrant visa applications filed after that date. During a 3-year period, aliens seeking to study at certified colleges or universities may be granted a nonimmigrant visa under certain clauses of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The amendments allow aliens to study at certified colleges or universities under certain clauses of the Immigration and Nationality Act, with requirements for accreditation by a recognized agency within a year of the effective date. Aliens can study at certified colleges or universities under certain clauses of the Immigration and Nationality Act, with requirements to comply with accrediting agency standards. The House of Representatives passed the document on August 1, 2012, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
